titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Benjamin and Muriel Goldring Papers TAM.374
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Jennifer Pondo, Daniel Michelson, and Gail Malmgreen, 2009-2010

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2012-03-29T19:36-0400

did.abstract: Benjamin (Ben) Goldring and Muriel Goodman Goldring were lifelong political activists. Ben, a lawyer by profession, served in the Abraham Lincoln Brigade in the Spanish Civil War, and later in the Pacific Theater during World War II. Both Muriel and Ben were active in the committees organized to fight the conviction and execution of the Rosenbergs and the imprisonment of Morton Sobell. As a specialist in civil liberties law, Ben gave his time and expertise to the Veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade (VALB) in their legal battle against the Subversive Activities Control Board from the 1950s to the 1970s; he was also a actiove member of the National Lawyers Guild. In addition to her work with the rosenberg and Sobell Committees, Muriel became involved in a wide range of local and national political causes. The Goldrings closely followed national political developments in many areas, from the peace movement to immigrants' and prisoners' rights, and were also community activists in Brooklyn, where they lived. The collection consists of the Goldrings' personal papers, materials related to Ben's service in the Spanish Civil War, background files on his legal practice and his writings on the law and legal history, files on Ben and Muriel's activities with the Rosenberg and Sobell committees, and political reference files on their many political and cultural interests.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Open for research without restrictions, except for Series VII.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content note
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of the Goldrings' personal papers, materials related to Ben's service in the Spanish Civil War, background files on his legal practice and his writings on the law and legal history, files on Ben and Muriel's activities with the Rosenberg and Sobell committees, and political reference files on their many political and cultural interests.

Series I: Personal Material, 1912-2000 includes personal correspondence, documents and memorabilia of both Goldrings and a number of members of the Goldring and Goodman families. Personal correspondence includes the couple's cards and notes to each other, Ben’s letters to his family while he was serving in WWII, and Muriel’sincoming letters from friends and relatives, including relatives in Israel starting in 1948.

Series II: Spanish Civil War, 1937-1995 consists mostly of correspondence between Ben and other veterans, as well as mailings, flyers, programs and other items from VALB. Also includde is Ben's correspondence from Spain to his family.

Series III: Legal Practice and Legal Research. 1931-2001 includes correspondence and research relating to cases Ben worked on and research notes, drafts and background material for published and unpublished articles. Several files document his work for the National Lawyers Guild, in particular his work on a document representing a dissenting view of the Guild’s 1977 report on Israeli treatment of Palestinian prisoners.

Series IV: Rosenberg and Sobell cases, 1951-2002 contains administrative files and publicity materials produced by both committees and files documenting the work of for those organizations. Notable is Ben's correspondence with Morton Sobell's legal team; Muriel's correspondence with Helen Sobell, and with Aaron Katz, director of the National Committee to Reopen the Rosenberg case; copies of material on the Rosenberg Trial released under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA); and a draft of a book-length work by William A. Reuben on the Rosenberg Case, with annotations by Ben Goldring.
Series V: Political Reference Files, 1939-2003. These files of clippings and printed matter cover a wide range of political groups, individuals, issues and events.
Series VI: Oversized Materials, 1900-1938 contains certificates and diplomas of several family members.
Series VII: Restricted Material, is mostly comprised of material relating to Muriel Goldring's illness, death and estate. For access, consult archives staff.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Benjamin (Ben) Goldring and Muriel Goodman Goldring were lifelong political activists. Ben, a lawyer by profession, served in the Abraham Lincoln Brigade in the Spanish Civil War, and later in the Pacific Theater during World War II. Both Muriel and Ben were active in the committees organized to fight the conviction and execution of the Rosenbergs and the imprisonment of Morton Sobell. As a specialist in civil liberties law, Ben gave his time and expertise to the Veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade (VALB) in their legal battle against the Subversive Activities Control Board from the 1950s to the 1970s; he was also a active member of the National Lawyers Guild. In addition to her work with the Rosenberg and Sobell Committees, Muriel became involved in a wide range of local and national political causes. The Goldrings closely followed national political developments in many areas, from the peace movement to immigrants' and prisoners' rights, and were also community activists in Brooklyn, where they lived. The collection consists of the Goldrings' personal papers, materials related to Ben's service in the Spanish Civil War, background files on his legal practice and his writings on the law and legal history, files on Ben and Muriel's activities with the Rosenberg and Sobell committees, and political reference files on their many political and cultural interests.

Benjamin Goldring was born in 1912 and died in 2000.He was a lawyer by trade, educated at Erasmus Hall High School and Brooklyn College. He graduated from Columbia Law School and passed the New York State Bar in 1934. A veteran of the Spanish Civil War, he fought on the Republican side as a member of the Abraham Lincoln Battalion from 1937-1938. Arriving in Spain on March 17, 1937, he first saw action at Villaneuva de la Canada and Brunete and was wounded five times, two of which required hospital stays. He was a member of the National Guard of New York State (1936-1937) and then of the US Army (1940-1941), re-enlisting in 1942 after Pearl Harbor, and serving in the Pacific theater until his honorable discharge in 1945. He was active in the Civil Rights Congress, and the National Lawyers Guild (NLG). Remaining active in social and political organizations, Ben wrote many articles and tracks concerning the law and its application. He also wrote in defense of the publication of a minority report on Israeli treatment of Palestinian prisoners as a counter point to the majority paper published by the NLG after a trip to Israel in 1977.

Among his notable legal activities were: assisting Carol King Esq. with the William Schneiderman Case, researching the possible transfer of Morton Sobell from Alcatraz, and representing a fellow Lincoln Brigade veteran before the Subversive Activities Control Board (SACB). He was gratified when, in the 1970s, the Lincoln Veterans finally won their long legal battle to remove the "subversive" stigma from the organization. Ben was also instrumental in obtaining the release of Lencio Pena (a decorated American soldier and Spanish citizen), imprisoned in Spain for anti-Franco activity. In 1982 he secured copies of the testimony of Lincoln Brigade veterans before the SACB and deposited them in the Lincoln Brigade archives, with his own notes on the case.

Muriel Goodman Goldring (1918-2007) was born, raised, and educated in Brooklyn, NY. She attended Erasmus Hall High School and took classes at Cornell University, City College of New York, and Brooklyn College. She worked at various times as an accountant and as a high school teacher, and was involved in amateur theater and traditional British folk dancing. She was a leading member of the National Committee to Reopen the Rosenberg case and the Committee to Free Morton Sobell, turning her hand to publicity, letter-writing, and the organizing of public events. These committees agitated first for a stay of execution for the Rosenbergs, and later for their vindication and for the release of Morton Sobell from prison. She became very close to Sobell's wife Helen.

Muriel and Ben were married in 1951, and stayed connected with their family and friends through extensive correspondence. They shared a passion for social causes and were aware of and or active in many liberal and radical organizations; they also shared a keen interest in cultural pursuits and foreign travel.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Collection is organized into 7 series: Series I: Personal Material, 1912-2000; Series II: Spanish Civil War, 1937-1995; Series III: Legal Practice and Legal Research, 1931-2001; Series IV: Rosenberg and Sobell Cases, 1951-2002; Series V: Political Reference Files, 1939-2003; Series VI: Oversize Materials, 1900-1938; Series VII: Restricted Material, 2006-2007.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the:
Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Elmer Holmes Bobst Library
70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012
Phone: (212) 998-2630
Fax: (212) 995-4225
E-mail: peter.filardo@nyu.edu

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number;
Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Elmer Holmes Bobst Library
70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.
